scenes.location: CADEN AND ADELE'S KITCHEN FALL 2005 SAME1

dialogues.speaker: A1INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Darkness. The sound of a radio and pots and pans clanging fades in. Caden, 40, opens his eyes in bed, and groggily looks at himself in the bureau mirror. The bedside clock reads 7:45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele, 40, in t-shirt and sweats, mixes a bowl of instant oatmeal, puts it in the microwave.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: ... a Labor Day luncheon today --

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mommy! Done! -- at Stuckey Hall --

dialogues.speaker: ADELERADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay!-- in downtown Schenectady -- Adele leaves the kitchen. Caden, also 40, enters as she's leaving. He's dressed in a ratty terrycloth robe.

dialogues.speaker: CADENADELE
dialogues.text: Morning. Morning. Tried not to wake you.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Thanks. You didn't. I was just -- As Caden's voice goes under, we follow Adele into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive, 4, sits on the toilet. Adele enters, rips some toi paper off the roll and proceeds to wipe Olive. The phone rings in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ADELECADEN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Caden, could you get that? It's Maria. I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Ugh. Caden! (looks at bright green smear on toilet paper) That's weird. The phone stops ringing.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Is something wrong with my poop? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELEMARIA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No, honey. It's just green.Hi, it's me. Where are you? Maybe you ate somethingI'll try you on your cell. green.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn't! What's wrong with me?! A cellphone rings in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Honey, I have to get this. You're going to be fine.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: But, Mommy -- Adele runs into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rifles through her purse, grabs her cellphone, answer

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Hey. (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wiping Olive's ass. You? Caden is pouring himself a cup of coffee. He sips it and stares out the window. It's raining.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're kidding! Holy fuck! Caden exits with his coffee, annoyed about the phone call

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I don't feel well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden passes the bathroom. Olive is staring into the toil bowl. Adele can be heard chatting in the background.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Daddy, my poop is green. Caden enters the bathroom, looks into the bowl at the gre feces and smeared toilet paper. He seems freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Am I going to be okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Of course, honey.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Did you have green poop when you were little?

dialogues.speaker: CADENOLIVE
dialogues.text: I'm sure I did, honey. Am I going to die?

dialogues.speaker: CADENOLIVE
dialogues.text: Of course not. You probablyI didn't! I didn't eat ate something -- green!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It'll be fine, sweetie. I'll be back in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: (CALLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is poop alive?

dialogues.speaker: 5EXT. CADEN AND ADELE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Caden steps out the front door in his bare feet and hurri down the driveway in the rain. He picks up the newspaper, pulls the mail from the box. As he heads back inside, he flips through the mail. There's a magazine called Attendi to your Illness addressed to Caden. A diseased person on cover. Across the street a gaunt man watches Caden, unsee

dialogues.speaker: 6INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Caden sits at the kitchen table with his coffee, reading paper, dated Friday, October 14, 2005.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: All right, baby. See you then. Adele clicks off her cellphone.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Harold Pinter died!

dialogues.speaker: ADELECADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Huh. Well, he wasOh wait. He won the Nobel old, right?Prize. Good for him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE OLIVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What?!Do you need to come look at my poop again?!

dialogues.speaker: ADELE OLIVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: No, Olive, it's fine. JustWhat if it's alive? What if flush.I kill it? It's green! Like plants!

dialogues.speaker: ADELE CADEN
dialogues.text: It's not alive, honey.God, remember that production of The Dumbwaiter I did at Albanyfest? The toilet is flushed.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Everything's alive. Everything grows big. That's how you know. Olive enters.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: I have your oatmeal, honey.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: I want peanut butter and jelly.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE OLIVE
dialogues.text: Olive, c'mon. You told me I don't want oatmeal. oatmeal. This isn't a restaurant. Adele growls, grabs the oatmeal, dumps it in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mommy! I'm sorry!(looking at paper) They found Avian flu in Turkey. In the country Turkey not turkeys. It's in chickens. Adele is making a peanut butter sandwich for Olive.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I watch TV till school? Caden clicks the remote for Olive and goes back to his pa A cartoon cow talks to a cartoon sheep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COW
dialogues.text: There is a secret, something at play under the surface, growing like an invisible virus of thought. The sheep nods. Caden pours himself some more coffee, ope the milk carton to pour some in, then sniffs at the spout He checks the date on the carton. It's October 20.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN COW
dialogues.text: Man. Milk's expired. Jesus. But you are being changed by it. Second by second. Every breath counts off time. Caden goes back to his paper. Adele puts a peanut butter sandwich in front of Olive.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Here. Now you better eat this.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE CADEN
dialogues.text: I will. The first black graduate of the University of Alabama died. Vivian Malone Jones. Stroke. Only 63. Adele stares out the window at the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden is in the dentist's chair, a bloody bib around his neck. The dentist, in surgical mask, probes his open mout calls out numbers to an assistant, who records them.
(to Caden) Family coming for Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden shaves. A faucet explodes and smacks him in the forehead. He is sent staggering backwards with a yelp, in the far wall, his razor flying and blood pouring from a jagged cut above his right eyebrow. Off-screen, we hear t pounding footsteps of someone running toward us. Half of Caden's face is covered with shaving cream. Rivulets of blood intermingle with it. Water shoots out where the tap was, spraying the mirror, which is spattered with blood. Adele, dressed in heavily paint-splattered clothes, hurri in and takes in the scene: the wet, the mess, the blood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Jesus! Caden! What the fuck -- ?! Olive, in a nightgown, stands quietly in the doorway, her curled toes clenched. She holds a large stuffed owl.

dialogues.speaker: CADENADELE
dialogues.text: Um. I was shaving and -- My God! Jesus! Look at your head! Dumbly, Caden tries to look up at his forehead, then squi nervously at himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Olive) Honey, don't look. Olive turns around.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put pressure. Press. Press!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Do I press above or below it?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: I don't know! Just... both! Caden sits on the toilet, presses a towel to his head. Ad squats, goes into a spasmodic coughing fit, finishes, ope the cabinet under the sink, pushes her arm through bottle cleaning products, old sponges, old toothbrushes, toilet paper rolls and other junk to the shut-off valves.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't turn it! It's gonna flood! Olive hugs the owl tightly and it speaks.

dialogues.speaker: OWLADELE
dialogues.text: Whooo. Whooo. Whooo areI can't -- Oh wait, got it! you? Adele turns off the water. Olive looks back into the room

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Mommy, Daddy has blood.

dialogues.speaker: 9INT. EXAMINATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Caden sits on a metal table. The room has some meager Christmas ornaments. A doctor stitches Caden's forehead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Caden squints into the bright light the doctor uses to se his work. In the background we hear another patient.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: (CRYING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, please, please... Caden sees a nurse shoving a tube far up into a man's nos Another nurse wipes away the blood leaking out his nostri

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Will there be a scar?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Probably. It looks like a mudflap.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I prefer there not be a scar.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: That fellow is annoying. He's in here every week. Like clockwork. The off-screen patient continues to whimper. The doctor finishes his work on Caden.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. I think that should -- He looks at Caden's eyes, turns off the bright lamp and l again. He turns the lamp back on and looks once more.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: What? The doctor feels Caden's pulse, then listens to his heart He presses hard against the glands in Caden's neck.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Changes in bowel movements?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: A little more yellow than usual. What?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I'd like you to see an ophthalmologist.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: A neurologist? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What? No, an ophthalmologist. I said, ophthalmologist.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Oh. The doctor stares blankly at Caden for a long moment, the looks suspiciously in Caden's ears.

dialogues.speaker: 10INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S CAR
dialogues.text: Adele drives and coughs spasmodically. The car swerves a Caden has a bandaged head and a prescription in his hand. Olive, in her car seat, sings. Caden sees revelers in win coats and party hats outside a house. They blow noisemake and yell "happy new year!"

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful day and the sun is shining and yellow. And the world is too big to understand and today is Tuesday and -- (SPEAKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, is today Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: No, it's Friday, honey.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And today is Friday and... Olive's singing continues but goes under.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: So what exactly did he say?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: My pupils weren't properly dilating and, um, not doing the opposite ...

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Constricting.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN ADELE
dialogues.text: No. Yes. The bump to the head?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: He doesn't know. Maybe. He said he doesn't think so. But maybe. But he doesn't know. But -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE CADEN
dialogues.text: Okay. I got it. Jesus.Sorry. I'm a little anxious.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Did you have to get a shot, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: No, honey. (to Adele) It's the start of something awful.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Do I have to get a shot?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: What? No. Of course not. (pause, to Adele) This is really fucked timing.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Caden.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN OLIVE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Bad timing.Did you tell him I have green poop?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remind me to call the (realizing) plumber, would you? I need aI have rehearsal! Fuck! to-do list. Caden!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN OLIVE
dialogues.text: Sorry.How many years till I have to get more shots?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not for a long time, honey. Caden pulls out a cell phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: A million years?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE OLIVE
dialogues.text: Remember Dr. Woodman said Dad, what's a plumber? after the last vaccination --

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: He's the man who -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE CADEN
dialogues.text: Or woman, Dad.Right. He's the man or woman who fixes sinks and toilets and... do you know what pipes are?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, Jim. I know. I'm sorry. I had an accident. No, I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Like to smoke out of?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Different kind of pipe. (into phone) Just run lines. I'll be there soon. 'kay. (hangs up) Houses have pipes. They're, like, tubes and they're behind walls and under the floor everywhere and -- Olive begins to whimper in horror.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: What's wrong, baby?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: (hushed anxious whisper) Every-single-where?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's okay. They just carry water to and from sinks and bathtubs and toilets. It's like in your body you have veins and ... um...

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Capillaries.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: And they're filled with blood. Olive is crying in earnest now.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: I don't want blood. I have blood? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: (to Caden) What are you doing? Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm trying to explain plumbing.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Well, stop it. (to Olive) It's okay, honey.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: (WEEPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want blood. Will it hurt? Will it hurt, Daddy?!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: No, honey, you're fine.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE CADEN
dialogues.text: I don't want blood! I don't (holding head) want blood! I don't wantI can't do this now. blood...

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: You don't have to worry, baby. You don't have blood.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think you should tell her she doesn't have blood.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Caden, stop it! Olive cries. Adele coughs. Caden stares out the window. I dark, but his pupils are pinpricks.

dialogues.speaker: 11INT. OPHTHALMOLOGIST'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: An ophthalmologist examines Caden's eyes. An eyeglass calendar on the wall is open to March 2006.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Thanks for getting me in right away. The doctor touches Caden's eye repeatedly with a small pr

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it the bump to the head? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OPHTHALMOLOGIST
dialogues.text: No. (writes in chart, then:) Could be. But I think we need to get you to a neurologist. Nothing urgent.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: A neurologist?

dialogues.speaker: OPHTHALMOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Yes, a brain expert.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN OPHTHALMOLOGIST
dialogues.text: I know what a neurologist is. Fine. I just thought from the way you asked --

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you said urologist. Why do I need to see a neurologist?

dialogues.speaker: OPHTHALMOLOGIST
dialogues.text: For a look-see. The eyes are part of the brain, after all.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: That's not true, is it?

dialogues.speaker: OPHTHALMOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Why would I say it if it weren't true?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It just doesn't seem right.

dialogues.speaker: OPHTHALMOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Like morally correct? Or right as in accurate?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. Accurate, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: OPHTHALMOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Hmm. Interesting. The doctor writes in Caden's chart.

dialogues.speaker: 12INT. SCHENECTADY THEATER
dialogues.text: Caden sits in the almost empty theater. A few people with note-pads are scattered around. Centerstage, a 1948 Dodge Business Coupe. The car is surrounded by various rooms fr that period: a kitchen, bedrooms, etc. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 12CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom, the actor playing Willy Loman, stands center stage. Claire, the actress playing Linda Loman, sits in the set' bedroom. Davis, the actor playing Biff, lies on the top b of a bunk bed upstage. A fourth actor, playing Happy, lie the bottom bunk.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: Willy, you coming up!!!!

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: Sssssh!!

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: Willy? Tom climbs in the car. CLAIRE (AS LINDA) (CONTГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўD) Willy? Answer me!...Willy! Tom starts the car and guns the engine. A brick wall off stage speeds into the car, accompanied by crashing and screeching sound effects. CLAIRE (AS LINDA) (CONTГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўD) No!!!

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS, (AS BIFF)
dialogues.text: Pop!! The wall continues to be pulled past the car crashing int the rest of the set, knocking walls over, creating havoc. lamp post falls and hits Claire, knocking her over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (running to stage)Yeah yeah, I'm fine. It's no Oh crap, Claire, are youbig deal. okay?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN DAVID
dialogues.text: David, what's happening here? (looking back from seat) Sorry, Caden. Hold on. David runs on stage to deal with the mess.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's too late in the game to be having these problems, David. (to Claire) You're sure you're okay?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIREDAVID
dialogues.text: God yes, it was funny.I know, Caden. I'm sorry. We'll get it. Tom emerges from the car, covered with stage blood. CADEN (CONTГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўD) Please. (to Tom) That was good, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah? I was trying something different. I was crashing differently. Ambivalently.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I saw that. I like it. Caden meets Tom at the foot of the stage. Behind them a group of technicians are lifting the wall and trying to r set it. Claire primps in the bureau mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try to keep in mind that a young person playing Willy Loman thinks he's only pretending to be at the end of a life full of despair. But the tragedy is that we know that you, the young actor, will end up in this very place of desolation.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (taking this in) Okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Great. Let's try it again. (CALLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Why don't you get cleaned up, Tom, and we'll go again. Tom exits. Caden rubs his temples, then heads to the back the house, pulling out his cell phone. He exits the theat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden passes the box office. Hazel, 35, sits inside, read a novel. She looks up, smiles warmly, and waves.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I just heard the death of the salesman.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: In more ways than one.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: (COMPASSIONATELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. (THEN:)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (holding up cell phone) In search of elusive signal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Signal's good here, oddly. She pats her lap in a friendly manner.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: That is odd.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I know! Cell phones, they're crazy!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN HAZEL
dialogues.text: (chuckles)(back in her book) See you in a few. Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden has the phone to his ear. He's squinting in the bri sunlight, pupils dilated. The gaunt man watches him unsee

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Dr. Heshborg said I should see Dr. Scariano. My pupils don't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel reads the first page of Swann's Way. The other volu of In Search of Lost Time are stacked neatly nearby. She looks up and sees Caden standing outside the box office window watching her.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I keep reading the first line. It's a good line, I think. But I don't know much about literature.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Maybe you should read the first line of another series of books.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I'm trying to better myself, Caden. Recommend me something. You're a genius; you must've read nearly a dozen books.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Exactly twelve. Have you read Kafka? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Um, I've read his name. A lot! I swear! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: His whole name?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Okay, not his entire name. Heinz?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should read The Trial, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: If you say so, I will. Can't wait till Wednesday. I'm so excited to see it.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I hope you like it.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: It's pretty impossible that I won't, you know. I mean... She trails off, shrugs. They smile at each other. Caden exits. Hazel looks at her book, re-reads the first senten

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden sits on the toilet. He finishes, looks in the bowl. His bowel movement is dark and loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele lies in bed asleep. Caden steps out of the bathroom and climbs into bed.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I think I have blood in my stool. Adele looks over, half asleep.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: That stool in your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden and Adele sit across from Madeline, 40's, their therapist. Silence. Adele has a coughing fit. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: When I was pregnant with Olive...

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: What was it like? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Um... I don't know. Hopeful or something. Like something was going to change.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Something did, no?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE CADEN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Yes. I mean... big time.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Maybe not as much as I had hoped. That's a terrible thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: There are no terrible things to say in here. Only true and false.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: I feel alone sometimes. I feel exhausted. Can I say something awful?

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Yes. Please do.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: I've fantasized about Caden dying and being able to start again. Guilt free. I know it's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: 19EXT. SCHENECTADY THEATER
dialogues.text: Caden sits sadly on the steps; drinks coffee. He watches Hazel pulls into the parking lot, gets out of her car. Th gaunt man is behind the trash bin. She sits next to Caden

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's a nightmare in there.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: The car crash?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Well... not only.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Sorry. So I'm reading The Trial.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah? You like? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Love. I'm such an idiot for not knowing about this book. (conspiratorial whisper) It's famous, it turns out.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: You're not an idiot. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Then you say, in fact, you're very bright, Hazel. And I love your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: In fact, you're very bright, (playing charmed) Hazel. And I love your eyes. Oh, am I? Oh, do you? Oh, darling!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Then what do I say?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I can't say what then you say.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Cause it's dirty. A whistling noise turns their heads. In the distance a ma with an unopened parachute is plummeting.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Jesus! They watch as the man falls behind a building. A scream. screech of brakes.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's gotta be dead. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden enters. The plumber is working on the sink.

dialogues.speaker: PLUMBER
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I've seen boy parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The studio is a mess, the floor covered with paint. Adele in her paint-spattered clothing, works on a tiny canvas, inch square. She paints with a single-hair brush while looking through a magnifying glass. Caden pokes his head

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Can I piss in your sink?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, I guess. Caden pisses in the sink in the corner of the studio. His urine is amber. He finishes and peeks over Adele's should through the magnifying glass at the painting. It's an amazingly detailed and angrily colored painting of a woma a state of profound despair, screaming to the heavens, wh standing in a field of flames.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's gorgeous, Ad.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Thanks. How was rehearsal?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Awful. We have five hundred and sixty lighting cues. I don't know why I made it so complicated.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: It's what you do.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Anyway, we got through it. I think you'll be impressed.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Caden, listen, I'm really sorry. I just can't go tonight. (off his look) I'm sorry. I've got to get two canvases ready to ship. By tomorrow. I know it sucks.

dialogues.speaker: CADENADELE
dialogues.text: But it's opening night.I know. I'm sorry. I would go if I could.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I have to get ready. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE CADEN
dialogues.text: I'll go tomorrow! We'll makeI mean, I can't take a dump tomorrow like the premiere! in your sink! What am I supposed to do? I have to get ready!

dialogues.speaker: 22INT. SCHENECTADY THEATER
dialogues.text: The theater is full. Caden stands nervously in the back. The lights dim. Hazel looks back from her seat at Caden a mouths the word "yay." He smiles. The curtain rises on a dark stage. Tom, as Willy, gets out of the car parked cen stage and walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: Oh boy, oh boy.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: Willy!

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: It's all right, I came back.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: Why? What happened? (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did something happen, Willy?

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: No, nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: You didn't smash the car, did you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: I said nothing happened. Didn't you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: Don't you feel well?

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: I'm tired to death. I couldn't make it. I just couldn't make it, Linda.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: Where were you all day? You look terrible.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: I got as far as a little above Yonkers. I stopped for a cup of coffee... maybe it was the coffee. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (AS WILLY)
dialogues.text: I suddenly couldn't drive any more. The car kept going off onto the shoulder, y'know? The audience is rapt. Caden relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: 23INT. QUINCY'S, BACK ROOM
dialogues.text: The cast party is in full swing. The opening was a succes Lots of drinking. Caden chats with Claire. Hazel watches from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (scrunching her nose) Ugh, I hated myself tonight. Plus I'm so bloated and enormous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No. You looked great. You I thought Tom was amazing! were great. I was very pleased.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Absolutely. (squints suddenly) Sorry. I have a bit of a headache.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (kisses his forehead) I just want to thank you for everything. You've been absolutely brilliant and it's going to be miserable going ahead without you.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'll be around. I'll check in. She gets teary, gives him a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: God, I'm such a baby. She just looks at him and smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to get drunk, that's what.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Ok, Claire. She backs away and gets lost in the crowd. Caden massages his temples. Suddenly Hazel is next to him.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I figured I'd better get in fast.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I loved it! And, by the way, Claire is trouble. And not terribly bright. Caden laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just wanted you to know the word on the street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: So you liked it?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I cried for like fifteen minutes after. I loved every minute of it. Except Claire. I thought she was weak.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Easy on the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Oh, Caden, not you, too. What I want to know is why she started crying in her last monologue, right after she had the line, 'I can't cry for you Willy...'?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She felt very strongly that it was right. They sip their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Where's el wife-o?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Had to work. Her Berlin show is in two weeks. We're going to spend like a month there.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Choo!

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Hooray! We've still got it! (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll miss you.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL CADEN
dialogues.text: You're going to miss you? Yeah, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I like you so much? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I couldn't begin to guess.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: (SIGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither. It must be that you're married. Do you get high, my friend?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Y'know. Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You want to now? With me. In my car.

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: I don't know.Come on, it's a party.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I get kind of... something when I'm stoned.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: What does something mean?

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: I don't know. Bothered?What does bothered mean?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Y'know... bothered. Horny.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: And me with a station wagon and all. Could be dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it really could.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You're absolutely zero fun.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: You know I wish I could.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Jesus, I like you. I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: You're not staying for the reviews? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I know it's brilliant. I don't need some dope with elbow patches telling me. She smiles, gives him a hug, and heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: 24INT. HAZEL'S CAR
dialogues.text: Hazel drives down a dark street, crying. People watch her passing car from various windows. There's a run-over dog, lit by a streetlight, glistening on the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Hazel studies the dog. It's a bloody, gutty mess, squashe flat. Against all odds, it's still alive. Its head is lolling. She bends down to pet it.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You're not going to make it, baby.

dialogues.speaker: 26INT. HAZEL'S BATHROOM, (APARTMENT)
dialogues.text: Hazel takes off her make-up, hair back in a clip. She watches herself blankly in the mirror, somewhat erased without eye make-up. The run-over dog is sleeping in a bo on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: 27INT. QUINCY'S, BACK ROOM
dialogues.text: The party has thinned out. The remaining people are sitti around a table, drinking. Claire, next to Caden, rests he head, sleepily drunk, against his shoulder. Caden studies series of lumps under the skin of his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm going to Berlin for a month for my wife's show. Then I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I wish I was your wife or a wife or had a wife. Or was German even. I'm so lonely with none of those things. A man walks in with a bunch of newspapers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yay or nay?

dialogues.speaker: 28EXT. BURNING HOUSE
dialogues.text: Hazel gets out of her car and walks up to a neat little h on a street of neat little houses. Faint swirls of smoke escape from the windows. She rings the doorbell. The butt is hot; Hazel pulls her finger away.

dialogues.speaker: 29INT. BURNING HOUSE
dialogues.text: The rooms are hazy. The realtor coughs a little. Hazel surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I've always loved this house.

dialogues.speaker: REALTOR HAZEL
dialogues.text: Yes. It's a wonderful place.The truth is, I never really imagined I could afford it.

dialogues.speaker: REALTOR
dialogues.text: The sellers are very motivated now.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: It's a scary decision. I never thought I'd buy a house alone. But, y'know, I'm 36, and I wonder what I'm really waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: REALTOR HAZEL
dialogues.text: Home-buying is always scary.But I mean with the fire and all especially.

dialogues.speaker: REALTOR
dialogues.text: It's a good size though, twenty-two hundred square feet. Not including the partially-finished basement

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL REALTOR
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm thinking IIt's a perfect size for should go.someone alone.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I like it, I do. But I'm really concerned about dying in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: REALTOR
dialogues.text: It's a big decision, how one prefers to die. Would you like to meet my son? Derek? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Derek, 40 and scruffily handsome, appears around a corner

dialogues.speaker: DEREKREALTOR
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom.Derek's living in the basement since his divorce. If that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden enters. Adele sits at the table across from Maria, They are drunk and eating nachos.

dialogues.speaker: ADELECADEN
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Hi, Caden. How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hi. It's late.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Maria came over to keep me company and we lost track. I'm sorry I missed the play. But I got everything done here. How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: We're a hit. Reviews are great. New York Times said it was brilliant to cast young actors as Willy and Linda.

dialogues.speaker: ADELEMARIA
dialogues.text: Great. That's great, Caden! Good for you!

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: I'll see it tomorrow. Tonight! Adele and Maria laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAADELE
dialogues.text: Jesus, it is late. Early!Can we get a ticket for I'd love to see it, too. Maria? Adele smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Are you stoned? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: A little. I don't know. Y'know? I mean, are you happy with it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Love to know what you think.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I think.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Absolutely! It's all about your artistic satisfaction, Caden.

dialogues.speaker: 31EXT. RESIDENTIAL SCHENECTADY STREET
dialogues.text: Caden and Olive walk along. Caden holds a tax envelope. H face has pustules on it. The gaunt man follows.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with your face, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's pustules. It's called sycosis. Spelled differently than psychosis, but it sounds the same.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: I don't know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Well, there's two different kinds of psychosis. They're spelled differently. P-s-y is like if you're crazy and s-y is like these things on my face.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: You could have both though.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I could. But I don't.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Okay, pretend we're fairies. I'm a girl fairy and my name is ... La-ru...lee. And you're a boy fairy and your name is Teeteree.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: What's my name again?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: La-ru-lee. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: No. I said ... La-ru-la...ay.

dialogues.speaker: 32INT. SCHENECTADY POST OFFICE
dialogues.text: Caden and Olive are at the back of the long line of peopl

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Pretend we fight each other. And I say stop hitting me or I'll die. And you say okay, but you're fibbing. And you hit me again.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's go. Hit me. They pretend to hit each other. Olive makes hissing and roaring noises. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. You have to stop hitting me now or I will die.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Okay. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: No! Pretend you're fibbing! Remember? He mock hits her again. She falls.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I have to die. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretend you say you don't want me to die.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I don't want you to die.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: (compassionate whisper) But I have to.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: But I'll miss you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: I have to. And you'll have to wait a million years to see me again. Caden tears up at this and tries to conceal it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I'll be put in a box. And all I'll need is a tiny glass of water. And lots of -- tiny pieces of pizza. And the box will have wings, like an airplane.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Where will it take you?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: (THINKS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Performance in progress. There is now a cemetery on stage Linda, Biff, and other characters stand around a gravesit Caden sits in the audience between Adele and Maria and hi parents. He glances over at Adele's stony face. Maria is drunk and blurry.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS, (AS BIFF)
dialogues.text: Let's go, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS LINDA)
dialogues.text: I'll be with you in a minute. Go on, Charley. I want to, just a minute. The other characters exit the stage. CLAIRE (AS LINDA) (CONTГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўD) (talking to the grave) I never had a chance to say good- bye. Forgive me, dear. I can't cry. (begins to cry) I don't understand it; I can't cry. It seems to me that you're just on another trip. I keep expecting you. Willy, dear, why did you do it? I search and search and I search, and I can 't understand it, Willy. I made the last payment on the house today. Today, dear. And there'll be nobody home. We're free and clearГѓВўГўВ‚В¬Г‚В¦ We're freeГѓВўГўВ‚В¬Г‚В¦ We're freeГѓВўГўВ‚В¬Г‚В¦ We're f (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The stage lights go dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden, Adele, Maria, and his parents walk along. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN ADELE
dialogues.text: I just --I don't know what it matters what I think.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I loved the story. So interesting.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN ADELE
dialogues.text: Because your opinion is --It was good. It was well done. It was very ... successful.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought it was wonnnderful!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Why were the old people so young?

dialogues.speaker: CADENADELE
dialogues.text: It was a choice, Dad. I'll Nothing. But nothing. explain later. (pause) (to Adele) I can't get excited about But? your restaging someone else's old play. There's nothing personal in it. CADENCADENГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўS FATHER I put my soul into thatI mean, they were younger thing. than their kids. That doesnГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўt make sense.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Do you really believe that tripe? CADENCADENГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўS MOTHER Wow. It's not tripe. Jesus.I liked that the old people were so young. It was interesting. ADELE (CONTГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўD) Ok, fine. But it's not you. It's not anyone. It's not real.

dialogues.speaker: CADENADELE
dialogues.text: People come out crying,Great. Be a fucking tool of saying their lives are suburban blue-hair regional changed and -- theater subscribers. But what are you leaving behind? You act as if you have forever to figure it out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Why are you being like this? Adele has a coughing fit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELECADEN
dialogues.text: I'm not being like anything. Are you seeing someone else?

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Is that your entire frame of reference for relationship problems?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: No. I don't know. It's a stressful time. Our shows. The whole health thing.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Oh, you're fine.

dialogues.speaker: 35INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Caden, in shorts and t-shirt, tiptoes past his parents, sleeping on the fold-out couch.

dialogues.speaker: 36INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Adele sits at the kitchen table with Olive. She drinks coffee and talks on the phone. Olive eats cereal and watc a cartoon. Caden enters. Olive doesn't look away from her show. A cartoon jackal talks to a man who looks like Cade

dialogues.speaker: JACKAL
dialogues.text: When you are dead there is no time. The world is a timeless rock. Caden pours a cup of coffee, sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I think I might have arthritis. Adele continues to talk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: No, I know. Exactly. Caden picks up the newspaper. It's dated May 25th, 2006. flips through, finds the obituaries and starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ok. All right. Yeah. Ok, bye. Adele hangs up the phone, looks at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: My joints are stiff. Who was that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Maria.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Right. It's been three hours since you spoke.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Caden, I think I want to go to Berlin with just Olive. Caden looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think it would be good for us. Silence. Caden's father appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN'S FATHERCADEN
dialogues.text: Morning, kiddos.(to Adele) Christ. Is this about last night? Caden's father smiles, nods, and exits.

dialogues.speaker: 37INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Adele packs. Caden sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question, Ad? She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have I disappointed you somehow? She starts to cry, hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Caden. I don't know. Y'know? I don't know what I'm doing. It's just a little time apart. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk when I get back. Everyone is disappointing. The more you know someone. The whole romantic love thing is just projection. Right? I don't know. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I love you. I don't know what I'm doing. We'll talk when I get back.

dialogues.speaker: 38INT. ADELE'S STUDIO
dialogues.text: Cobwebs. The room is long abandoned. Caden slumps against wall and stares into space. He starts to cry and can't st Later: Caden watches a paint-spattered TV. A commercial: diffused images of people flying kites, having picnics, watching sunsets. A shot of Caden among them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Flurostatin TR allows you to live life when it's your turn to face the challenges of chemotherapy. Ask your doctor if it's right for you. He feels the bumps on his arm, which have grown. He write down Fluorostatin TR. He starts to clean Adele's studio. Later: The room is sparkling. No more paint anywhere. Caden is on his knees, scrubbing the last bit of dirt. He sweaty and focused.

dialogues.speaker: 39INT. SCHENECTADY THEATER BOX OFFICE
dialogues.text: Caden, neatly groomed, leans on the counter chatting with Hazel. Her crushed dog sleeps on the floor in a box.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: We should get a drink. Be fun.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Be weird.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I like weird. I like you. See? He doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway. I don't want to make you uncomfortable. I just thought it would be a fun diversion. Okay, I do want to make you uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Haze. I wish I could.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You can, Cade. You can! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I have an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Crease.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: It's just a word. Don't get all bent out of shape. Jeez.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I won't. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The masked dentist probes Caden's mouth.
(to Caden) Some fives this time. Not good. Keep with the flossing. We'll see in three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden sits across from Madeline.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN MADELINE
dialogues.text: I'm lonely.Yes. Anything else? Caden notices Madeline's feet in too-small shoes. There a visible blisters and band-aids on her feet.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN MADELINE
dialogues.text: I'm hurt.Yes. And?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN MADELINE
dialogues.text: I think Adele's right whenWhat would be real? she says I'm not doing anything real.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm going to die. They don't know what's wrong with me. I want to do something important. While I'm still here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: That would be the time to do it, yes. I have a book that might help you get better.

dialogues.speaker: CADENMADELINE
dialogues.text: Better?Yes. It's called Getting Better.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Who wrote it?

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE CADEN
dialogues.text: I did. Oh. (goes to full bookcase)(looking at titles) All of these.Wow. I never knew that.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Wow. Yes, wow. Wow indeed. She hands Caden the very thick book. He flips through it, catching words and snippets here and there: Clairaudience ... vaginal juices... The echo began ... Plumbing ... Cat eat rats ... Me who am as a raw nerve ... Crease.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's forty-five dollars. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden finds a website online for Madeline Gravis. Amazing graphics. She is touted as one of the foremost psychologi in the world, a sought-after public speaker, advisor to w leaders. Her book Getting Better has sold millions of copies and is translated into fifteen languages. In a box at the bottom is a photo of a smiling Caden; it reads: Theater Director Caden Cotard says, "It'll change my life

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dentist probes Caden's mouth. The Hygienist writes th numbers.
(to Caden) I'm going to recommend a periodontist. He'll probably recommend gum surgery.

dialogues.speaker: 44INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Caden is on the phone. His legs are elevated and his pant legs are rolled up, revealing swollen, discolored calves.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm looking for... I'm sorry, I don't speak German. No. I'm --

dialogues.speaker: 45INT. QUINCY'S
dialogues.text: Caden sits by himself in a booth, reading the self-help b

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: We must live in the present moment. The now. The now. The now. Caden tries to be in the present moment as a women sings about gingivitis on a small stage in the back.

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: How do you know if youГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўve got   gingivitis? / HereГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs an experiment,   Go ahead try this: / Brush your   teeth, then spit in the sink / Does   it come out red? / Do they say your   breath stinks?  ItГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўll only get worse, thatГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вў the beginning / Your mouth will be  cursed, thereГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs no hope of winning  / Necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis   is next / Also called trench mouth,   / youГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўll never get sex.   Later: Caden nurses a beer. He seems unwell. SINGER (CONTГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўm just a little person  One person in a sea   Of many little people   Who are not aware of me.  I do my little job  And live my little life   I eat my little meals   Miss my little kid and wife.  And somewhere   Maybe someday   Maybe somewhere   Far away  (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SINGER (CONTГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„ВўD) IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўll meet another little person   Who will look at me and say   I know you  YouГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўre the one  IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўve waited for   LetГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs have some fun   Life is precious  Every minute  And more precious   With you in it.   So letГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs have some fun.   LetГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs take a road trip  Way out west  YouГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўre the one  I like the best.  IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўm glad I found you  Like hanging ГѓВўГўВ‚В¬Г‹Вњround you   YouГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўre the one  I like the best.  Hazel plops down across from him. She has a smudge of soo on her nose.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hey! Thanks for meeting me. He points to his nose. She wipes at the soot on hers.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: God, I'm delighted. Thought you'd never ask. You did ask, right?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I didn't want to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Who does? (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look like you feel well.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm going through some things.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You want to tell me about it?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I can't really. But I'm meditating and running and taking vitamins. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cutting out sugar. I can't really say any more. It's ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Ok. Tell me something else.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: You tell me something. Oh. I've cut out wheat.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Um, I bought this really nifty sweater today. On sale. Fifty dollars reduced from three hundred!

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.It's cashmere. So very soft. You must feel it. Hazel holds her arm out. Caden touches it.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: What do we do with all this, Hazel?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I don't know. We fuck? We continue to sort of flirt? You divorce your wife and marry me and I make you happy for the very first time in your life and all your symptoms disappear? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call it a day? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't choose the last one. I just said that one for effect.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Do I have to choose at all?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: No, I suppose not. Choosing is not your strong suit. You want to come over to my place, Cotard?

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: Um ... I'm won't let you off the hook by saying "never mind" this time.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Adele is only on vacation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: She hasn't called you since she left. You've left countless messages. It's been a year. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's been a week.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: (stares at him, then:) I'm going to buy you a calendar. Caden rips a cocktail napkin into little pieces.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Okay, just for one drink. Hazel smiles and stands. She scoops up the torn napkin pieces and puts them in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Scraps for my scrapbook. Caden watches her ass as she turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel drives. Caden follows in his car. We see him in her rearview mirror, peering into her car. Hazel hikes her sk and causally begins to play with herself with her right h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel fixes drinks, mixes them with her right index finge She hands Caden one.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I really can't drink very much because of my condition.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Caden's mysterious condition. Well, have one sip, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Did you put something in it?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Would you like me to have? A little love potion, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Sure, why not?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: If that's what it takes, consider it done. Poof! Love potion number 69. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Caden laughs and takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's good. She takes a sip of her drink. Caden drinks some more of h

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Does it make you want to kiss me?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Kind of.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Tell me why?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Um, I feel a lot of longing.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Hmm. Beg a girl, why dontcha.

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: Um, okay. Please, Hazel, let On your knees. me --

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I'd like you to beg me on your knees for a kiss. Just for fun. Dumbly, Caden gets down on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Why am I doing this?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: (smiling warmly) For fun, baby.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: You'll help me forget my troubles?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Oh, kiddo, you don't even know.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I have a wife.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You have me. And I adore you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden and Hazel have violent sex. Hazel watches Caden's contorted face. They finish and lie there. Caden starts t weep.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm sorry. What?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm just so confused. I'm sorry. I'm really sick. I think I'm dying. I have a kid. I'm married.

dialogues.speaker: HAZELCADEN
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. Oh, fuck me.I'm sorry. It's terrible, I know.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I just thought this might change things. I hoped. Ugh.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (still crying) I had a good time. I think you're a very nice person. Really.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: That is just the wrong thing to say right now, Caden. You should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (CRYING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad I finally got you.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's Caden! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Caden! I can't wait to see you and Olive on the 12th. um... I went someplace without you tonight, Ad. I went some place you couldn't come with me. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: What? Who is this? Oh, I have to go. There's a party. I'm famous!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Oh. Ok. Great. Have fu -- The connection is lost. Caden sits there, looks at the 20 tax form in front of him, goes into convulsions. He manag to grab the phone, his hand flopping all over the dial.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: 911. What's the problem, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm sick.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: We're out of ambulances, miss, but we'll send a taxi. Please wait in front of your house, miss.

dialogues.speaker: 51INT. HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: Caden waits on a plastic chair in a dimly lit hallway, hi beat-up suitcase at his feet. He reads a very old Vogue a opens to a spread about his wife. She seems glamorous. There are photos of her in Berlin, her work, her flat. Sh the toast of the art world. Photos of her with two men, a also with Olive, who seems somewhat Nazi Youth-like now.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Cotard? He looks up, having forgotten where he was. He grabs his suitcase and follows the nurse down a dismal hallway: gur against dirty walls, empty wheelchairs. Skinny man takes flash picture of Caden. Nurses drinking coffee out of pap cups eye him. Puddles of vomit on the floor. They arrive the end of the hall. A doctor pokes his head out of a roo He studies a file and doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Cotard?

dialogues.speaker: 52INT. SMALL EXAMINING ROOM
dialogues.text: The doctor never looks up from the files. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You've had a seizure of sorts.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What does that mean?Seems to be some synaptic degradation. Fungal in origin. Autonomic functions going haywire.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's serious?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We don't know but yes. They both sit there in silence for a long while.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll get you enrolled a biofeedback program. Maybe you can learn some sort of manual override.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden waits in line, holding a big wrapped box, addressed Olive in Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden sits on the couch, wheezing and reading a dictionar entry for the word "crease." The definition is "n. a fold He squirts artificial saliva in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden is having periodontal surgery. It's bloody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden, with swollen lower face and bleeding mouth, approa the box office with a gift-wrapped box. Hazel looks up. T damaged dog barks.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL CADEN
dialogues.text: Be quiet, Squishy.Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Caden, I won't be yet another woman you feel guilty about. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Here. Take this. I got like five for Christmas. Goddamn Christmas. She hands him a 2009 calendar. It features photos of Adel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele calender on wall, open to March. Caden reads Gettin

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Now. Now. Now! Be here now!

dialogues.speaker: A59INT. ADELE'S BERLIN APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Adele feeds a piece of paper into a fax machine. A fax starts to come in. Caden watches as the words appea fuzzy as if there is some interference in the process. Olive wanted me to ask you not to read her diary. She lef it under her pillow by mistake. Glglf n mesr-siy. Hewz we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden lifts the bed pillow and finds a kid's diary. He studies it, puts it back. There's a knock at the front do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden opens the front door. A man hands him an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeline's feet are swollen and bloody. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN MADELINE
dialogues.text: So I just got this MacArthurOh, Caden! Grant last night.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN MADELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. A lot of money. Do you know what you're going to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: A theater piece. Something big and true and tough. Y'know, finally put my real self into something.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINECADEN
dialogues.text: Oh, Caden! What is your realI don't know yet. The self, do you think? MacArthur is called "the genius grant." And I want to earn it.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: That's wonderful. God bless! I guess you'll have to discover your real self. Right?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, yeah. Oh, I wanted to ask you, how old are kids when they start to write?

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Varies.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Could a four year old keep a diary?

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Listen, there's an absolutely brilliant novel written by a four year old.

dialogues.speaker: CADENMADELINE
dialogues.text: Really?Little Winky. By Horace Azpiazu.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Aww. Cute.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Hardly. Little Winky is a virulent anti-Semite. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The story follows his initiation into the Klan, his immersion in the pornographic snuff industry and his ultimate degradation at the hands of a black ex-convict named Eric Washington Jackson Jones... Johnson... Jefferson, with whom he embarks on a brutal homosexual affair.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Wow. Written by a four year old? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Azpiazu killed himself at five.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: That's horrible.

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: He would've written so much more had he lived. They developed a method -- some software -- to determine what he would've written had he lived to ten, twenty, thirty, etcetera.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: Which part?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Any of it. Why did he kill himself?

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: I don't know, why did you?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MADELINE
dialogues.text: I said, why would you?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Oh. I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: 62INT. OLIVE'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Caden paces nervously. He sits on Olive's bed and jimmies open her diary with a screwdriver. He reads:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Deer Diry. Thank you for being my new best frend. My name is Olive Cotard. I am for yers old. I like choclit and --

dialogues.speaker: 63INT. SCHENECTADY TOY STORE
dialogues.text: Caden looks at the toys.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: -- my favorite color is pink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a Christmas present for my daughter. Something pink.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: How about this? The clerk holds up a pink box with a picture of a nose on

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yes. That's good.

dialogues.speaker: 65INT. QUINCY'S
dialogues.text: Caden sits with Hazel. She seems somewhat distant.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: The idea is to do a massive theater piece. Uncompromising, honest. I don't know what it is yet or how to do it, but it'll come. It'll reveal itself.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Huh. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: HereГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs what I think theater is: itГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs the beginning of thought. The truth not yet spoken. ItГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs a blackbird in winter. The moment before death. ItГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs what a man feels after heГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs been clocked in the jaw. ItГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs love... in all its messiness. And I want all of us, players and audience alike, to soak in the communal bath of it, the mikvah, as the Jews call it. WeГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўre all in the same water, after all, soaking in our very menstrual blood and nocturnal emissions. This is what I want to try to give people, Hazel. And I want your help. Hazel just stares. The food arrives. Caden looks at his plate and concentrates. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Salivating. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to concentrate. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biofeedback training.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: So I was wondering if you'll help.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: In your box office?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: No. Like as my assistant.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I can work with you, Caden. I'm kind of angry.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I just want to normalize it, Hazel. I think we'd have fun together. He swallows some food then concentrates. She watches him.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I miss you. He concentrates some more. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm digesting.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: It's really disturbing.

dialogues.speaker: 66INT. TINY, CRAMPED REHEARSAL HALL
dialogues.text: Caden, beads of sweat on his forehead, sits with a large group of actors, Tom, Claire, and Davis from Salesman amo them. No one speaks. Finally, Caden clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: We'll start by talking honestly. Out of that a piece of theater will evolve. I'll begin. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (long pause) I've been thinking a lot about dying lately.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You're going to be fine, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I appreciate that, Claire, but --

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRECADEN
dialogues.text: Well, you are. You poor regardless of how this thing.particular thing works itself out, I will be dying. So will you.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRECADEN
dialogues.text: Caden!So will everyone here. And I want to explore that unflinchingly. There is a long silence as everyone looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are all hurtling toward death. (SILENCE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet here we are, for the moment, alive. Each of us knowing we will die; each of us secretly believing we won't. Nobody says anything for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It's brilliant. It's brilliant. It's everything. It's Karamazov.

dialogues.speaker: 67INT. CADEN AND ADELE'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Caden is in bed, reading Olive's diary.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Dear diary. Germany is wonderful! So many friends here. My new dads are great and handsome. And brilliant directors of theater. Caden grimaces in pain for a moment. His mouth bleeds. He dials the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL'S ANSWERING MACHINE
dialogues.text: It's Hazel. Leave a message or don't. Your dime. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hi. I haven't heard from you so I thought I'd say hi. Hi, Hazel! He giggles crazily, coughs, then hangs up, embarrassed, grimaces once more, then dials again.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CADENCLAIRE, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: Hi, Claire, it's Caden.Hi! I was just thinking about you!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Um, I was calling to say hi, chat about today maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (PHONE VOICE)
dialogues.text: Hi! Here you are, on my phone!

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Do you maybe want to get a drink or something? It's late so --

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Yeah! Yeah yeah yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden waits in a booth, nursing a martini, watching peopl walk in, but not Claire. After a bit, Hazel enters with Derek from the burning house. She's laughing and doesn't Caden. He slinks back into the booth. They sit at a table not far from Caden, who can hear their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HAZELDEREK
dialogues.text: (giggly) I'm just asking. Stop!

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You are so obnoxious!

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: You're so obnoxious.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you find it awfully charming. My obnoxiousity.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Obnoxiousity is not a word. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You don't want to cross me.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Don't I?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: No. Because you like me so much.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: True. I like your obnoxiousity.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
