dialogues.text: Caden rides up. The elevator stops. Old Person #1 gets on with a big bloody bandage covering his nose.

dialogues.speaker: OLD PERSON
dialogues.text: Hello, Ellen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 132CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Caden nods. They continue the ride in silence.

dialogues.speaker: 133INT. 31Y BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Caden looks at the unmade bed, an imprint of a female for the sheets. He touches it. He gets a melancholy look on h face. He lies on his back in the form. He sees a note on the night table:

dialogues.speaker: ADELE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hi Ellen. Crackerjack job last night! Would you do sheets again? We had quite a fuck last night and it's musky and gross. Kisses, A. Caden smells the sheets, strips the bed.

dialogues.speaker: 134INT. 31Y KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Caden sips coffee at the kitchen table. He's writing a no

dialogues.speaker: CADEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hi Adele. Relined the cabinets. Just wanted to let you know I won a MacArthur Grant and I'm mounting a play, which I think is going to be pure and truthful. Best -- Caden hesitates for a moment, then signs it "Ellen."

dialogues.speaker: 135INT. WAREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Caden and Hazel watch as Claire waits in her bathrobe in kitchen and Sammy enters the "apartment."

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Caden, what are you doing at night? I have a right to fucking know.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: I've been going to Adele's place. And cleaning it. Long pause. Caden rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Do you know what I've given up for you? For this. For you. For you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.I -- I thought I wanted to be just a working stage actress. But, y'know, I'm watching all the young girls crowding me out and it's -- There's a knock on the door. Sammy just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get the door. Please. Just... Sammy opens it. Tammy, playing Hazel, stands there.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. This looks serious. Am I interrupting?

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: What's going on, Hazel?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Just wanted to tell you the girl playing me is able to start today.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Oh, good. That's good.That's all we need around here, two Hazels.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll take that as my cue. Tammy closes the door and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Maybe you can clean her toilet.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Maybe I will.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It's over, Caden.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Claire, no.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to you. Claire turns to Caden. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I didn't say I was going to clean Hazel's toilet. He did.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: But you thought it. There's a silence. Hazel watches Caden closely.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I thought it. But I didn't say it. Claire packs up her stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I got an offer to do Needleman in a Haystack and I'm going to take it. I want you out of the apartment. The real one. You can keep this one. Claire heads down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Jesus. Claire! Please!

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Already put out a call for a Claire replacement. Would you really clean my bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (beat, sadly) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: God, Caden, it's all so fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden digs in his bag, pulls out a sponge, gets on his ha and knees and scrubs the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden, wearing a pair of magnifying glasses that flip up down, enters a crowded gallery of people wearing similar glasses. The paintings are microscopic. Museum visitors u the special glasses to study the paintings. There's a wal inscribed "Small Miracles: The Paintings of Adele Lack." Biographical info is under. Caden squeezes his way to the wall to look at paintings. He sees one of an African fema genital mutilation ceremony; (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: a woman weeping over the grave of a child; a man raping a woman. He comes to a wall titled: "Women I Love." He sees a self-portrait of Adele, a portrait of Maria, a portrait Olive, naked and covered in tattoos. Then he comes to a portrait entitled "Ellen Bascomb." He steps back for a second, unable to look. The people behind him are impatie Finally he flips the glasses and studies the painting. El appears to be a chubby, 40 year old white woman, her mous brown hair tied back in a kerchief. She is naked and spreading her vulva for the viewer. She has a kind face a what appears to be an appendectomy scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden moves boxes. Claire sits at the kitchen table with actor. They are rehearsing lines from Needleman in a Haystack.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS REBA)
dialogues.text: Oh, Needleman, you had such   potential. But IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўm afraid IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„В going to have to move on.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR, (AS NEEDLEMAN)
dialogues.text: Just like that? You donГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўt give a  guy even a chance?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS REBA)
dialogues.text: IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўm not a chance-giving girl. IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬Г a fun-loving girl. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR, (AS NEEDLEMAN)
dialogues.text: I try to be fun-loving. See?  Needleman makes a funny face. Reba doesnГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўt

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS REBA)
dialogues.text: My analyst says you have complexes.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR, (AS NEEDLEMAN)
dialogues.text: Once you enjoyed NeedlemanГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs  complexes.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS REBA)
dialogues.text: ThatГѓВўГўВ‚В¬ГўВ„Вўs before my analyst taught me  that my enjoyment of them was a   sign of my suppressed non-  enjoymnent of them.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR, (AS NEEDLEMAN)
dialogues.text: I hate your analyst.  (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (AS REBA)
dialogues.text: She told me your hatred of her is a   sign of your latent homosexuality.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: This is the end of my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIREACTOR
dialogues.text: Bye.Bye. Caden heads out the apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Caden enters the apartment next door and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's filled with boxes. Caden hears laughter coming from next door. He puts his ear against the wall to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden exits, crosses the street, and looks up, trying to in Claire's window. He sees her walk by, then nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden sits with Hazel at a table facing the giant, open apartment building structure. An actress plays Claire. Sh sits at the kitchen table of her apartment with an actor playing the actor. They both hold scripts and read from Needleman in a Haystack. Sammy is in front of the buildin looking up. Caden looks troubled. Tammy sits to the side Hazel and studies her. Every once in a while, Hazel self- consciously glances over at Tammy, who does not avert her gaze. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: This is a lie! Caden paces. The actors stop what they're doing, sit with their legs dangling off the edge of their apartments, wai for instructions. Caden limps off to the set designer's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden enters the office. Will, the production designer, l up from his drafting table.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Wall it up.

dialogues.speaker: 143INT. WAREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Sammy stands across the street from the walled-up apartme building, an exact replica of the real one. He looks up a Claire's lighted window. Caden watches, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: 144INT. CADEN'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Caden, hooked up to pumps, tries to sleep on the floor, surrounded by boxes. He listens to Claire having sex next door. He detaches his pumps, gets dressed.

dialogues.speaker: 145INT. 31Y BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Caden sits on the bed and reads a note from Adele:

dialogues.speaker: ADELE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Good for you with your grant! Listen, I fixed up the walk-in as a sort of bedroom if you want. We'd love to have you and you wouldn't have to schlep all the way to Queens. Just a thought. Kisses. A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden sees an unmade cot in the corner and a few cardboar boxes marked "Stuff for Olive." The "Olive" is crossed ou and replaced with "Caden."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boxes are empty as Caden finishes making the bed. The room is decorated in a girly manner. Pink bedspread. Girl lamps and furniture. Girly prints on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: 148EXT. CITY SET, (INT. WAREHOUSE SET)
dialogues.text: Sammy, walking with a cane, exits his apartment building and walks down the street. Caden and Hazel follow. Sammy passes people, nods hello to some. He stops at a newsstan and buys a paper. The set seems to go on forever.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Eventually Sammy arrives at a warehouse that looks exactl like the warehouse they are in. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Inside it looks exactly like the warehouse, including a duplicate city set. Sammy hands little scraps of paper to people, then dumps his pack on the table where Tammy sits Hazel and Caden watch.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Morning, Haze.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Hi, Caden. How was your night?

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Okay. Yours?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Eh. Philip was colicky. I was up all night. Caden looks over at Hazel for confirmation. She nods, slightly freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: (to Tammy) Sorry. Everybody here?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: (looking at clipboard) Sammy's not here. Jimmy called and said there's some subway problem. Jimmy rushes into the warehouse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sorry. Sorry, sorry, sorry. (SWEETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Hazel.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Hi, Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: (to Tammy) Sammy likes you. Caden looks at Hazel. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hazel, could you get everyone situated? I need to speak to Will about some new sets. Sammy pulls some Polaroids out of his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah. We'll take it from June 9th? Sammy nods, heads toward the set designer's office.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. I need to do that, too. Haze, keep an eye on things?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Yup. June 9th? Caden nods, rushes out the door of the warehouse set.

dialogues.speaker: WAREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Caden finds Will up on some scaffolding, working on the s

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Will, I need you to build this. Caden hands Will shots of the exterior and interiors of Adele's building and of apartment 31Y.

dialogues.speaker: 151INT. WAREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Caden sits at his desk. There are several overweight wome waiting on the other side of the partition. Hazel ushers in. She's a ringer for the painting of Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hazel, what do you think of this title: Unknown, Unkissed, and Lost?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Eh. Caden this is Millicent Weems.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hi, Millicent. Have a seat. How are you at cleaning?

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: (SITTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very, very good at it.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Because this part requires a lot of it. You'd play a cleaning lady.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: I played Egga the cleaning lady in Hedda Gabler at the Roundabout.

dialogues.speaker: CADENMILLICENT
dialogues.text: Great. Okay. And Mrs. Dobson in Scrub-a- Dub at the Pantages.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: You're weirdly close to what I've visualized for this character.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: Glad to be weirdly close. Millicent and Caden study each other.

dialogues.speaker: 152EXT. CITY STREETS, (INT. WAREHOUSE SET)
dialogues.text: Caden heads to the warehouse set. He hands paper scraps t shopkeepers, pedestrians, a guy sweeping the street.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Good work, everyone. Nobody acknowledges him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden enters the warehouse set. Tammy sits alone at the c table. There's activity on the street and movement can be seen in various windows.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Where're Sammy and Hazel? Tammy jerks her head to the left. Caden sees that Sammy h Hazel with her back against a wall. They are talking intimately. Caden approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Sammy, what are you doing? Sammy and Hazel look over casually.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Hi, Caden. I'm being you. You like Hazel; I like Hazel.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: This Hazel doesn't exist for you. If you want to like a Hazel, like that one. Caden points indicates Tammy. Sammy squints over.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMYHAZEL
dialogues.text: That's what I tried to tellAw, no harm, no foul, Caden. him! It's Equity break anyway. (LOUD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes, everybody! The actors playing the people on the street immediately s what they're doing. Actors pour from apartment buildings shops, lighting cigarettes and talking on cell phones. Sa goes off.

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL
dialogues.text: Hazel. What?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't like him, do you?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Kind of. He reminds me of you.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm me. You don't need someone to remind you of me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Caden. I like you more. I do. Sammy's just fun.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm fun.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Oh, sweetie. No, you're not. Caden's cell phone rings. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes?Is this Caden Cotard?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes.This is Officer Mark Mellman of Schnectady P.D.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes?I'm sorry to inform you, your mother has been the victim of a home invasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funeral is in progress. Caden stands with Tammy and his father as his mother's coffin is lowered into the ground. The coffin is banged up and crumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of mourners. Caden sits on the couch with Tammy.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Was my father standing with us?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I don't know what he looks like.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: He's dead. He looks dead, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Probably wasn't him then.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: A little moustache? She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CADE
dialogues.text: Anyway, Thanks for coming with me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I asked Hazel but she was busy tonight and you're the next best thing. I mean, it isn't that you're the next best thing but because you play her, it feels comforting. Does that make sense? Although the thing is offstage you're nothing like her. You play her very well though. Did Hazel mention what she was doing tonight because I called her house before we left and her husband said she wasn't going to be back till late and I thought that was weird because she told me Philip was sick.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: She's going to dinner with Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (CALMLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's interesting.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMYCADEN
dialogues.text: He's supposed to like me.I'll have another talk with him. Can you excuse me. I need to use the bathroom. Caden gets up and turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Don't forget your phone.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Yammy. Caden takes the phone and limps off.

dialogues.speaker: 155EXT. CADEN'S MOTHER'S BACK DECK
dialogues.text: Caden talks on his cell.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hey. What you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel's driving while talking on her cell.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: In my car. Heading to dinner with Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me that before?

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Caden. I don't want to say things that are going to make you sad.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It mostly makes me sad that it doesn't make you sad.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You want me to be sad that someone's taking me out to dinner? I don't know how to do that.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I want you to be sad that we had something really special and it's going away!

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: It just happened, Caden. I didn't plan it. You were with Claire. This probably isn't going to go anywhere, sweetie. I'm still your girl.

dialogues.speaker: CADENHAZEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, Haze. C'mon. It's just dinner. He's got stories! It just seems fun.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: He has stories about me!

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Caden, I know everything about you and it's all adorable. I love you and I always will. So don't worry. I gotta go, I'm there. Hazel hangs up. Caden stands there for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house has emptied out. Caden and Tammy straighten.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Did you always want to be an actress?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Every girl wants to be an actress.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I did. So I figure everyone does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like there's been a horrible struggle. The bed is covered with blood. Caden and Tammy stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I thought someone would've cleaned it up.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I don't know! Someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a kid's room. Caden and Tammy stand there.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: This is my room. You can sleep here.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Where will you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: The living room couch.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Don't you want to sleep with me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN TAMMY
dialogues.text: Um... It's just sex.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Okay. If you think it's okay. Tammy laughs, matter-of-factly gets undressed in front of Caden. He just stands there uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How can you be like that?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I get undressed every day.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: In front of someone is different.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I don't see why.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Maybe because you have a beautiful body. Maybe that makes it easier.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I suppose it might. Do you want to fuck?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I do. Yes. Um. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: It'd be fine. Caden starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm very lonely. I don't know what's wrong. I just -- I'm sorry. Can you understand? Do you understand loneliness?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, I don't know. I feel okay mostly. Fucking might help.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: It's okay. I don't mind. Take your clothes off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: You're very pretty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I were pretty like that.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: You wish you were a chick?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (long pause) Sometimes I think I might've been better at it.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Interesting. It's kind of a drag in a lot of ways. You like guys?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: No. No. I like women. I only like women.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm getting cold. She climbs into bed.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take off your clothes. Caden does, awkwardly and shyly. He then stands there nak Tammy smiles sweetly at him.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pretty Caden.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thank you for saying that.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Come to bed, Pretty Caden. Caden turns off the lights and climbs into the twin bed w Tammy. She looks at his face, then kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: 159INT. CADEN'S CAR
dialogues.text: A residential street in Schenectady. Caden drives and Tam sits in the front passenger seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: What is attractive? How are attractive people treated, how do they feel? How do unattractive people feel, how are they treated? How do attractive people feel about unattractive people, how do unattractive people feel about attractive people? How do unattractive people feel about other unattractive people? How do attractive people feel about other attractive people? How do unattractive men feel about unattractive women? How do unattractive men feel about attractive women? How do attractive men feel about unattractive women? How do attractive women feel about unattractive men? How do old people feel about attractive people? How do attractive people feel about old people? This is my study. Caden slows down.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: That's Hazel's house. Caden points to the house with smoke seeping out the wind

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Huh. Do you think we should have a Hazel's house on the set for me?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: It would be verisimilitudinous.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don't know. I have to speak to the fire marshal.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: It would be very verisimilitudinous if you could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel drives a golf cart along a fake highway. Caden and Tammy sit in back. Hazel eyes them in the rearview mirror They seem cozy. Hazel scowls. Technicians are on the side of the road putting in plants and trees.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I think both of you Hazels are going to like this. Turn off here. Hazel rolls her eyes, drives down an exit ramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazel drives the golf cart down the street in a state of completion. She stops in front of a replica of her house.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hank! Okay! The house begins to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: My house! Tammy kisses Caden on the cheek and runs into the house.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Is there no end to your pussy kissing?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: It's verisimilitudinous. I'm thinking of that as a title.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Whatever. I've got work to do. Tell your girlfriend to get out here if she wants a ride back.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: She's not my girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Give it a rest, Caden. I can smell her on your breath.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tammy! We have to get back.

dialogues.speaker: 162INT. APARTMENT HALLWAY, (INT. WAREHOUSE SET)
dialogues.text: Sammy walks down the hall followed by Tammy. He stops at various doorways and listens to conversations or other no within the apartments. They are followed by Caden and Haz

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Jeremy is playing to us. Tell him he simply needs to talk to Donna. We'll hear what we hear. Tammy takes down the note.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Sammy's explaining too much. Feels expository. Needs to be shorthand, like, "Jeremy big." Hazel writes that down. They all continue down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Caden? Can we stop for a second?

I think then Hazel could have a good moment where she cries or gets angry. I'm not sure which yet, but it feels dramatically sound.

dialogues.speaker: HAZELCADEN

dialogues.text: Did you cry?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: You're making progress.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Okay, I cried a little before. (long pause) Hazel, you've been part of me forever. Don't you know that? I breathe your name in every exhalation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: (STOPS)

dialogues.text: Oh, Caden. Oh, fuck. What the fuck are we doing?

dialogues.text: I don't know. Hazel latches her pinky around Caden's. Sammy has been watching the whole thing from behind a pillar. Caden glan at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I know how to do it now. There are nearly thirteen million people in the world. Try to imagine that many people! None of those people is an extra. They're all the leads of their own stories. They have to be given their due.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The actor playing Sammy is in the coffin. There's an enormous crowd. Tammy plays Hazel and weeps. A stand-in f Sammy as Caden stands next to her. Caden and Hazel watch from the director's table.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Do you see what I'm saying? Hazel has her head in her hands. She looks over at Caden, imploringly.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Come over tonight? Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Yeah. I miss Olive. And the other one. The retarded one.

dialogues.text: I'm a bad person. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: No you're not. I'm a badI am. I should never... have person.gone out with Sammy. I was just trying to get to you.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: My heart aches so much for you.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: We're here, Caden. I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm aching for it being over.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. The end is built in to the beginning. What can you do?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: God. You're just perfect.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL
dialogues.text: I'm a mess. But we fit, don't we. They kiss, then Hazel climbs into bed.

dialogues.speaker: HAZEL

dialogues.text: (climbing into bed) I'm embarrassed. I just want you to know it's not you. And it's not me. It's the medication. They are tender and quiet and intensely focused. The smok in the room is dense. When it's over, they lie there quietly, with the occasional cough from both of them. Cad cries quietly.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CADEN

There follows a slightly delayed and staticky translation, in an accented male voice, of everything Oli says, with a delay between what Caden says and Olive's response, as she listens in translation.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm dying, as I'm sure Maria told you. The flower tattoos have become infected and they're dying. So I am, as well. This is life. Olive pulls down her hospital gown a bit to show Caden th now sickly and decayed flower tattoos.

dialogues.text: It's Maria. She did this.

dialogues.text: Maria gave me reason to live once you left. The flowers defined me.

dialogues.text: Your mother and Maria took you away. I tried for years to find you. I didn't leave you.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE
dialogues.text: You did something. Caden is affected by this. It resonates.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVE, (CONT'D)

The scene in the play is dull. People walk back and forth aimlessly. Various passersby on the street have hacking coughs. Tammy steps out of the bathroom, meanders over to the director's table. Hazel's sweater is on Michael's cha back. She casually pulls it off and tries it on. Caden watches. She looks so much like Hazel now, it's unbearabl He looks away. Millicent walks by carrying a mop and buck

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: Caden Cotard is a man already dead, living in a half-world between stasis and antistasis. Time is concentrated and chronology confused for him. Up until recently he has strived valiantly to make sense of his situation, but now he has turned to stone.

dialogues.text: Okay. That sounds good.

They watch the "Sam Funeral" scene replayed with actors playing Tammy playing Hazel and an actor playing the stand-in for Sammy playing Caden. Tammy has her head in her hands. She looks over at Millicent, imploringly.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Come over tonight? Please?

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Ok, take off the sweater. Tammy takes off the sweater, puts it on the chair back.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I'm hot.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: Yes, you are.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Smile shyly at each other. They do. It lingers. Millicent looks over at the funeral scene. It's dull and static.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: This is tedious. This is nothing. Millicent touches Tammy's hand, heads over to the funeral scene. She whispers things to some actors, has longer conversations with others.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: He's directing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: She's not getting the feel of you, Caden. You don't move around. You don't talk to people. It's not --

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: Okay, folks, let's run it! The scene comes alive with specific activity: weeping Haz a little boy in the back playing with dirt clods, a man a woman eyeing each other flirtatiously from a distance, an woman with Parkinson's fiddling with Rosary beads, a well dressed woman squatting and peeing near a gravesite. A  minister addresses the mourners.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Everything is more complicated than   you think. You only see a tenth of  what is true. There are a million   little strings attached to every  choice you make; you can destroy  your life every time you choose.  But maybe you won't know for twenty   years. And you'll never ever trace  it to its source. And you only get  one chance to play it out. Just try   and figure out your own divorce.  And they say there is no fate, but  there is: it's what you create.   Even though the world goes on for   eons and eons, you are here for a   fraction of a fraction of a second.   Most of your time is spent being  dead or not yet born. But while   alive, you wait in vain, wasting  years, for a phone call or a letter   or a look from someone or something   to make it all right. And it never  comes or it seems to but doesn't  really. And so you spend your time  in vague regret or vaguer hope for  something good to come along.   Something to make you feel  connected, to make you feel whole,  to make you feel loved.   (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the truth is I'm so angry and  the truth is I'm so fucking sad,   and the truth is I've been so  fucking hurt for so fucking long   and for just as long have been   pretending I'm ok, just to get   along, just for, I don't know why,   maybe because no one wants to hear   about my misery, because they have   their own, and their own is too  overwhelming to allow them to  listen to or care about mine.  Well, fuck everybody.  Amen.  Soon it starts to rain. Thunder rumbles. People pull out umbrellas. Caden looks up, surprised that such a system i rigged here.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Caden sits with Michael at the director's table and stare into space. The actors are doing what they've always done milling, walking to and fro. Millicent, holding hands wit Tammy, heads up the walk to the Hazel's house set.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Millicent. She turns. He waves her over. Tammy sits on the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was ... spectacular.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It really was! Delightful!

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENTCADEN
dialogues.text: Thanks.I'm out of ideas. I'm dead.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: Oh. I... could take over... as you... for a bit. Until you feel refreshed.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! Caden, looks sideways at Michael, remains silent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I think you're tired, Caden.Yes. I think you just need All these years of creative some time. To regroup. work.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I need to keep my hand in.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT
dialogues.text: Well, Ellen needs to be filled.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Filled? You mean...?

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Her role. Just for a bit. It's a choice role. Just until you're refreshed.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do like to clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden sits on the unmade bed and reads the note:

dialogues.speaker: ADELE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ellen, Olive has died. It's a time of overwhelming grief so please forgive my mess; I haven't been able to get out of bed. Until today. Much affection, A. Caden crosses to the window and looks up at the night sky even though it's clearly the ceiling of the warehouse. A tiny plane flies by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden walks down the hall carrying a bag of garbage to th incinerator chute, dumps it in, and turns back to apartme 31Y. Old Person #2 (actor version) is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: OLD PERSON
dialogues.text: Ellen? Is your name Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: OLD PERSON
dialogues.text: Caden asked me to give you this. You're to keep it in all the time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 182CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Old Person #2 (actor) hands Caden a small black button. Caden examines it. Old Person #2 (actor) points to his ow ear, in which he wears one. Caden sticks it in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ... touched by the sadness of Adele's neighbor. So close to death. Reminds me of granny. I should really call her. Remember how Granny Bascomb bounced me on her knee pretending to be a horsie. I loved that so much. Say thank you to Adele's neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: OLD PERSON
dialogues.text: (pause, listens, then:) You're very welcome, young lady.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Now say, have a very good day.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Have a very good day.

dialogues.speaker: OLD PERSON
dialogues.text: (pause, listens, then:) I will indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark. Caden lies in bed, attached to his pumps.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ... miss him. Why did he have to get bored with me? Everyone gets bored with me. I'm not very bright. And since I put on that weight, I don't get the looks I used to. It's not that bad. Lots of people have it worse. I've got a job and place to stay. Adele is nice to me. And so smart and talented. I don't understand her artwork, but that's just me. I wish I'd gone to college. I feel stupid around educated people like Adele. Eric was too smart for me, too. We didn't talk at all near the end. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd try to tell him about my day and he'd get this far away look in his eyes. I kind of felt sorry for him; he seemed so miserable with me. I guess -- Caden drifts off to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: 184INT. ELLEN'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: A tenement apartment. Ellen, in a terrycloth robe, is at stove making scrambled eggs. Toast pops from the toaster Ellen crosses to get it. She passes a mirror, glances at herself, seems momentarily surprised, pushes a wisp of ha behind her ear and continues to the toaster. Eric enters. He's an unhealthily thin middle-aged man. He doesn't acknowledge her, nor she him. He pours himself coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I'm making eggs. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything okay, Eric?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Everything's everything.

dialogues.speaker: 185INT. ELLEN'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen sits on the bed with a cup of coffee and stares out window. There's a city park across the street and she watches kids play basketball. She begins to weep.

dialogues.speaker: 186EXT. FIELD
dialogues.text: It's spring and a ten year old girl watches her mother as lays out a picnic on a blanket on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Ellen, why do you look so serious?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I'm going to remember this moment for the rest of my life, mama. And in exactly twenty years, come here with my daughter and have exactly the same picnic.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Baby, that's the loveliest thing I've ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: 187INT. ELLEN'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen lies in bed watching Eric sleep next to her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: There was supposed to be something else. I was to have something. A calm. A love. Children. A child, at least. Children. Meaning. I am always on the verge, never more than a tiny shove from tears. I can feel them in my chest now. That squeezing pressure. And it is so tempting to let go, but I am afraid, the next time maybe, I will never stop crying. I miss my husband even though he is lying here. He hates me. Oh God. I have disappointed him and he hates me. The one person who should be able to see me and he won't look. He will never look again.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Caden lies on his back, and opens his eyes. His pumps dro

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: (quietly, mournfully) Eric. Caden looks over. No note from Adele. He gets out of bed, glances in the mirror, seems surprised by his reflection.

dialogues.speaker: 189INT. 31Y BATHROOM, (INT. WAREHOUSE SET)
dialogues.text: Caden sits on the toilet and pees. He wipes himself.

dialogues.speaker: 190INT. APARTMENT 31Y, (INT. WAREHOUSE SET)
dialogues.text: Caden vacuums the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: My period is late this month. I wonder what's going on. I'm bloated. I wish it would come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden lies in bed reading a Judith Krantz novel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I can't believe she said that to him! She's a slut, anyway. He sticks a bookmark in the book, puts it on the night ta turns off the light, and lies on his back with his eyes o

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe I can ask Adele for a raise. It's been three years. I do a good job. God, I'm so tired tonight. I'm getting old. I'm lonely here.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Caden awakens. He switches off his pumps. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Get up. Look at the night table for a note from Adele. Caden gets up and glances at the night table. A type-writ

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Adele died of lung cancer last night. You may stay on if you like.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Look shocked. Weep. Caden looks shocked, then weeps.

dialogues.speaker: MILLICENT'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go into the kitchen and -- The voice stops. Caden stops. He waits. Nothing. He takes out the earpiece and looks at it, shakes it, then slips i back in his ear. Nothing. He waits. In the distance he hears wailing and gun shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are out. Caden sits on the bed, still waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden sits on the bed, his head slumped against the headboard, sleeping. Distant explosions wake him. He open his eyes and sits up straight, and waits. He taps his ear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is very dark. Caden exits apartment 31Y. Old person #2 (actor) stands in the hallway and faces away, unmoving. Caden walks past and nods. Old person #2 does n respond. Caden presses the elevator button. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLD PERSON
dialogues.text: There's nobody running it anymore. Caden looks at Old Person #2 and nods.

dialogues.speaker: 197INT. WAREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Dark. The unfinished, back-of-a-facade of the set is apparent. Caden walks down endless plywood stairs. The bowels of the building: fake water pipes, electrical cord

dialogues.speaker: 198EXT. CITY STREET, (INT. WAREHOUSE SET)
dialogues.text: No lights. Vague daylight drifts in from high warehouse windows, from which cardboard has fallen. Deadly quiet, abandoned. Caden passes the occasional body on the street Fires smolder in buildings. The streets are flooded with sewer water. Buildings are draped with massive tarps. Beh a fence are piles of bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes the Hazel's House set, burnt to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arrives at the warehouse set and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted here too. The same occasional fires, flooding, d bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caden walks, soon arriving at the warehouse set within th warehouse set. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: WAREHOUSE SET
dialogues.text: Another dark, deserted street, more bodies, fires, floods Caden panics. He pulls out his earpiece, shakes it, and p it back. He walks.

dialogues.speaker: WITHIN-WAREHOUSE SET
dialogues.text: He arrives at the warehouse within the warehouse within t warehouse. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: WAREHOUSE-WITHIN-WAREHOUSE SET
dialogues.text: Deserted. Caden walks. He gets in a golf cart and drives through the deserted street sets.

dialogues.speaker: WAREHOUSE-WITHIN-WAREHOUSE SET
dialogues.text: Caden reaches the beach set, and drives the cart on the s He sees footprints. He gets out and follows them, spots a woman ahead walking with a suitcase. He hurries as much a he can with his limp, his weakness, his ancient body, to catch up with her.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Hello. The woman turns. She's middle-aged, face radiating kindne

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Mostly dead. Some have left.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Would you sit with me for a moment? I'm very tired. And lonely. The woman smiles at Caden. They sit on a log.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel like I know you.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I was the mother in Ellen's dream. Perhaps from there.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Yes! That's it. Yes. You seem a bit older than I remember.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (CHUCKLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That dream was quite a while ago. He's silent. The woman touches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to say you look old. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: Everyone's dreams in all those apartments. All those secrets we'll never know. That's the truth of it -- all the thoughts nobody will ever know.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry the experiment didn't work. I wanted it to with all my heart. I wanted to do that picnic with my daughter. I feel I've disappointed you terribly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: No. No. I am so proud of you. Caden starts to tear up.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: All I want is someone to see me, someone to look at me with kindness. For me to be the most special person in the world to just one person.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I know, baby. I know. He looks at her tentatively. She's looking into his eyes directly, clearly, kindly. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to be fine. Caden starts to weep so hard he chokes. Strings of snot p from his nose. The woman holds him, gently takes off his wig, and strokes his sparse hair. He looks out over her shoulder at the dark empty city at the far end of the warehouse. His rheumy eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: CADEN
dialogues.text: I know what to do with this play now. I have an idea. I think -- The screen goes black fast.
